fol.18r
May it please yo
r
good L. I can not cer-
tifie as yet, howe Count Maurice hath spedde
in
e enterprise of Hulst: For there is nothing
yet written to
e
Councel of state
. And I trust
yo
w
are informed of some that are present,
and may sooner advertise. It is nowe, as we
conjecture,
at he doth execut his purpose. But
o
r
hope at
e Hage is muche diminished, for that
e Enemie, we heare, was forwarned of his com-
ming. There hath bin lately some
treaty between
e general states and
e Lady
of
Anholt
of
e house
of
Battenbourgh
,
that her
towne of Anholt, upon
e frontiers of
e Countie
of
Zutphen
towardes
Cleveland
,
w
ch
hath alwaies
hitherto taken part w
t
e Enemie, might heere-
after be permitte d to keepe it self neutral.
The state at her instance will yelde unto it,
upon condition that an other place of strength
adjoining unto Anholt, w
ch
is called
Bredevoord
or Breefoort, belonging to
e said Lady, but of
more importance to
e Enemie, may hold the
same neutrallitie. Whiles this motion is
in treaty, about 4 daies agoe,
Cap
t
Lambert
w
t
certaine Englishe companies of
Duisbourgh,
not knowing, as I suppose, w
at
mater was in
hand, upon certaine intelligence w
t
some in Anholt,
went soddainly thither, sca
led
e wales, and
possessed
e towne. W
ch
was done w
t
e losse of
some fower of
e souldiers. But
e towne hath
a castel of greater force, w
ch
they could not
then surprise. The next day after
at
e towne
was taken, there were certaine Englishe men
missing of
e better sort, among w
ch
were bothe
the brothers of
S
r
Francis Vere
: w
ch
were knowen
fol.18v
to be there, when
e Alarme was given, but not to
be found, when
e towne was taken. This was
so written hither
e next day after: and sins I
have heard no more. The towne was hardly
worth
e taking, being full of poore people, and
not to be defended against
e Enemies forces.
Because they were in parley about a neutrallitie,
they are not yet resolved heere, w
at
course they should
take w
t
e Lady of Anholt. The Enemie
lieth still in his former places. But all o
r
adver-
tisments signifie, that he goeth certainly for
France
about
e end of this moneth.
And thus I
humbly take my leave. From
e Hage.
Sep
t
9 1591.

r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
